     137             : 
     138             :     /* There are three kind of indexing operator: fast(long), [long] &&
     139             :      *(long):
     140             :      * - fast does ! perform automatic bound wrapping
     141             :      * - [] performs automatic bound wrapping, hen forwards to fast
     142             :      * - () is an alias to [] && directly forwards to []
     143             :      *
     144             :      * For each indexing operator, we have three variant: &, const& && &&:
     145             :      * - & means the numpy_iexpr has been bound to a non-const value, as in
     146             :      *``b=a[i] ; print b[j]``
     147             :      *   in that case the return type if the dim of a is 2 is a reference, to
     148             :      *allow ``b[j] = 1``
     149             :      * - const & means the numpy_iexpr has been bound to a const value, as in
     150             :      *``np.copy(a[i])``
     151             :      *   in that case the return type if the dim of a is 2 is a value (||
     152             :      *const ref)
     153             :      * - && means the numpy_iexpr is a r-value, which happens a lot, as in
     154             :      *``a[i][j]``
     155             :      *   in that case the return type if the dim of a is 2 is a reference.
     156             :      *   It is a bit weird because we return a refrence from a rvalue, but the
     157             :      *reference is bound to
     158             :      *   the buffer of ``a`` that is ! temp.
     159             :      */
     160           0 :     auto fast(long i) const & -> decltype(numpy_iexpr_helper<value>::get(*this,
     161             :                                                                          i))
     162             :     {
     163           0 :       return numpy_iexpr_helper<value>::get(*this, i);
     164             :     }
     165             : 
     166             :     auto fast(long i) & -> decltype(numpy_iexpr_helper<value>::get(*this, i))
     167             :     {
     168             :       return numpy_iexpr_helper<value>::get(*this, i);
     169             :     }
     170             : 
     171             :     auto

     375             :   // Indexing an numpy_iexpr that has a dimension greater than one yields a
     376             :   // new numpy_iexpr
     377             :   template <size_t N>
     378             :   struct numpy_iexpr_helper {
     379             :     template <class T>
     380             :     static numpy_iexpr<T> get(T &&e, long i);
     381             :   };
     382             : 
     383             :   // Indexing an iexpr that has a dimension of one yields a qualified scalar.
     384             :   // The qualifier is either:
     385             :   // - a reference if the numpy_iexpr is a ref itself, as in ``b = a[i] ; b[i]
     386             :   // = 1``
     387             :   // - a reference if the numpy_iexpr is a r-value, as in ``a[i][j] = 1``
     388             :   // - a value if the numpy_iexpr is a const ref, as in ``b = a[i] ; c =
     389             :   // b[i]``
     390             :   template <>
     391             :   struct numpy_iexpr_helper<1> {
     392             :     template <class T>
     393             :     static typename T::dtype &get(T const &e, long i);
     394             :     template <class T>
     395             :     static typename T::dtype &get(T &&e, long i);
     396             :     template <class T>
     397             :     static typename T::dtype &get(T &e, long i);
     398             :   };
     399             : } // namespace types
